answers.author: Karen Harrington
answers.text:
In Minnesota, the state and counties have been working for several years to identify a core set of metrics for essential human services, as part of a broader effort to improve human services results.  The site for the Steering Committee on Performance and Outcome Reforms is here:  http://www.dhs.state.mn.us/main/idcplg?IdcService=GET_DYNAMIC_CONVERSION&RevisionSelectionMethod=LatestReleased&dDocName=dhs16_147237.  In addition, page 4 of their final report to the state legislature has a table with the metrics they selected, and can be found here:  http://www.dhs.state.mn.us/main/groups/agencywide/documents/pub/dhs16_172908.pdf.
If you would like a contact, who can help you, let me know and I'll put you in touch with several folks.

answers.author: Gerald Young
answers.text:
Building upon the comments and documents shared here, ICMA is interested in your opinions of what health and human services measures work best and which are most meaningful to city/county managers in comparing your performance to that of other jurisdictions. 
Over the last 12 months, ICMA has been conducting significant evaluation, research, and design efforts to restructure its performance management activities and facilitate the analysis of just such issues.  High level changes include:  
Streamlined service areas and a focus on core and outcome measures, shifting the data collection burden from roughly 5,000 individual measures to 500 
 New, state of the art software platform with improved reporting and analytic capabilities 
 New service levels that appropriately focus on the performance management and analytic activities undertaken by your community and provide a clear course for development 
To inform our survey update efforts, ICMA is creating short-term task forces on this and other service clusters to ensure that we build our revised performance management program on the metrics most relevant and meaningful to local government decision-making.  Task force members would be chosen to ensure broad geographic representation and various local government types.  Those selected would be asked to commit to attend two web conferences.  The task force will meet on Tuesday, March 18, at 2pm EDT.  
Please email Gerald Young at gyoung@icma.org if you are interested in serving on this task force.

answers.author: Mary Morrison
answers.text:
The City of Tacoma and many other communities are participating in STAR (Sustainability Tools for Assessing and Rating Communities) to help track community efforts in seven goal areas, including Economy and Jobs; Education, Arts and Community; Equity and Empowerment; Health and Safety. Each goal area has community outcomes, indicators and actions that are well-thought out and developed specifically for local government. You can learn more at www.starcommunities.org

answers.author: Donald Gloo
answers.text:
One starting point might be the County Health Rankings web site at http://www.countyhealthrankings.org, which is a product of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the University of Wisconsin Population Health Institute. 
The web site uses publicly-sourced data in areas such as access to health care, quality of care, tobacco use, alcohol use, birth outcomes, and diet and exercise to calculate an overall score and rank for (nearly) every county in the US. The web site has a convenient mapping feature, and all of the data can be downloaded for in-house analysis.

author: Sandra Slappey
text: I'm looking for examples of community indicators that would be relevant for human services. I see lots of examples of community indicators that address issues such as crime rates, graduation rates, commercial real estate vacancy rates - various descriptors that tell you something about the community. We'd like to put some together that address issues relevant for human services, such as indicators related to physical and mental health conditions, child safety, adults with disabilities, etc. Is anyone aware of a community that has done something like this?
title: Community Indicators for Human Services
